content: The "Travel America Now Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. The findings section follows. Prior to September 11, 2001, over 19 million Americans were employed in travel and travel-related jobs, with an annual payroll of $171.5 billion. The travel and tourism industry grew to be the third largest industry in the US, with over $582 billion in expenditures in 2000, generating $99.6 billion in tax revenues. In the same year, the industry created a $14 billion trade surplus for the US. The travel and tourism industry in the United States has grown to be the third largest industry, with over $582 billion in expenditures in 2000. It generated $99.6 billion in tax revenues and created a $14 billion trade surplus for the US. After the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, efforts were made to ensure travel safety and maintain traveler confidence. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for revitalizing the US economy post-9/11 attacks. Collaboration between the industry and government is focused on ensuring safe travel and maintaining traveler confidence. Urgent short-term measures are needed to support the industry and retain economic stability. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for revitalizing the US economy post-9/11 attacks. Urgent short-term measures are necessary to keep working people employed and generate cash flow to support the industry's economic stability. The public should be encouraged to travel for personal and business reasons to stimulate the economy. SEC. 25C. PERSONAL TRAVEL CREDIT is a new section that provides a credit for personal travel expenses. The new section SEC. 25C allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint filers. The credit allowed for qualified personal travel expenses is capped at $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint filers. Qualified expenses include travel by various means and lodging at commercial facilities, excluding expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The term 'qualifying personal trip' refers to travel within the United States with a destination at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence, including expenses for travel by aircraft, rail, watercraft, or motor vehicle, and lodging at commercial facilities. This does not cover expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The term 'qualifying personal trip' means travel within the United States with a destination at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence, involving an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and taken on or after the date of the enactment of this section. The term 'qualifying personal trip' refers to travel within the United States at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence, involving an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and taken after the enactment of this section. It does not include travel where expenses are deductible for a trade or business or income-producing activity. The term 'commercial lodging facility' includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. No credit is allowed under this section if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer for the same individual in a taxable year. No credit is allowed under this section if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer for the same individual in a taxable year. Additionally, the taxpayer must substantiate expenses with adequate records or evidence. The taxpayer must substantiate expenses with adequate records or evidence to claim the credit. No double benefit is allowed for expenses that qualify for both a deduction and a credit. The taxpayer must substantiate expenses with adequate records to claim the credit. No double benefit is allowed for expenses qualifying for both deduction and credit. Sec. 25C. Personal travel credit applies to taxable years after enactment. Temporary increase in deduction for business meals and entertainment. The amendment allows for a temporary increase in the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses, changing the limitation from 50 percent to 100 percent for expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. The effective date for this amendment is for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. NET OPERATING LOSS CARRYBACK FOR TRAVEL AND TOURISM INDUSTRY. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for up to 5 taxable years. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for up to 5 taxable years, as defined in subsection (j) for a taxable year that includes any portion of the period beginning on or after September 12, 2001, and ending before January 1, 2002. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for up to 5 taxable years, as defined in subsection (j) for a taxable year that includes any portion of the period beginning on or after September 12, 2001, and ending before January 1, 2002. The term 'travel or tourism loss' is defined as the lesser of the net operating loss for the taxable year based on income and deductions. The term 'travel or tourism loss' is defined as the lesser of the net operating loss for the taxable year based on income and deductions attributable to travel or tourism businesses. The term 'travel or tourism loss' includes the active conduct of a trade or business directly related to travel or tourism, such as commercial transportation, lodging, operation of airports, and provision of services within transportation facilities. The term 'travel or tourism loss' encompasses businesses directly related to travel or tourism, such as commercial transportation, lodging, airport operation, travel agency services, convention facilities, and other specified services. The term 'travel or tourism loss' includes businesses related to travel or tourism, such as commercial transportation, lodging, airport operation, travel agency services, convention facilities, and other specified services. Coordination with subsection (b)(2) treats travel or tourism loss similarly to specified liability loss. Taxpayers can elect a 5-year treatment. The Secretary coordinates travel or tourism loss with subsection (b)(2) similar to specified liability loss. Taxpayers can elect a 5-year carryback without regard to subsection (b)(1)(H). Taxpayers may elect to have the carryback period for a loss year determined without regard to certain subsections. This election must be made by the due date for filing the taxpayer's return and is irrevocable once made. Taxpayers can elect to extend the time for filing their return for the year of a net operating loss, which becomes irrevocable once made. Additionally, regulations allow a taxpayer with a 5-year carryback for a travel or tourism loss to credit the loss against taxable income of any member of a controlled group of corporations. Regulations allow a taxpayer with a 5-year carryback for a travel or tourism loss to credit the loss against taxable income of any member of a controlled group of corporations. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending before, on, or after the date of the enactment of this Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as stated in article I, section 8 of the US Constitution.
